div.sent: We see various types of plants in the environment around us;
some of these plants produce flowers and fruits and some do not.
Again some plants live for one or two years while the others survive for many years and provide us with shade, flowers and fruits.
Besides, there are some plants which have soft stems and some others have large and hard stems.
In addition, some plants are autotrophic, parasitic and saprophytic.
We have learnt about such classifications of plants in the previous class.
In this class, we shall study the classification of plants based on their environment.
The environment of plants growing at a particular place consists of soil, water, wind, sunlight, and other living materials around them.
Different plants grow under different environmental conditions.
The plants that grow in water can not survive in land.
Again plants growing in deserts are not able to grow in aquatic habitats.
All land plants can not grow in saline soil or water.
Botanists have divided plants into four classes on the basis of the availability of water and salinity prevailing in their habitat.
Hydrophytes: Plants which grow in water or places having water are known as hydrophytes.
Such aquatic plants grow abundantly in rivers, canals, lakes, ditches, ponds, and other aquatic habitats.
Free Floating : The floating plants which freely float on the water surface are known as free floating hydrophytes.
They are almost devoid of roots.
Some foaling plants possess floating roots but there is no root hair in them.
Instead of root hair, root pockets are found in them.
The upper surface of leaf is provided with waxy coating and stomata.
Examples of free floating hydrophytes are: Lemna, Eichhornia, Wolffia, Singara, Agolla etc.
Rooted floating hydrophytes: Plants with floating leaves and flowers and with roots embedded in underwater-mud are regarded as rooted floating hydrophytes.
Water lily, lotus, Euryale (Makhna) etc (Fig. 17.2) are examples of such hydrophytes..
They can float even on the deep water surface because of the presence of long petioles.
Adaptations of plants: Naturally each plant survives and reproduces in its own environment.
If this environment is changed due to some reasons, the plants also undergo changes in their nature and physical structure.
Adjustment of the plants with the new environment in this way is regarded as adaptation of plants.
Adaptations of aquatic plants : Adaptations of aquatic plants may take place in many ways.
Submerged hydrophytes: Plants which always remain under water are termed as submerged hydrophytes.
Plants such as Vallisneria, (Patashaola) Hydrilla, Potamogeton (Patajhajhi) etc belong to this type.
The stems of such plants are very soft, weak, slender and green.
Amphibious hydrophytes: Plants which grow partly in water and partly on land are known as amphibious hydrophytes.
These plants grow by the side of water bodies but extend their stem long distance up to the water surface.
Examples of amphibious hydrophytes may well include Jussia (Keshardam), Ipomoea (kalmisak) Enhydra (helencha) etc. body because of the presence of epidermis with thin covering.
For this reason these plants do not require well developed root hair.
These plants can adjust with water current and movement of aquatic animals owing to the presence of wavy, thin, soft and slender stems.
If the stems were hard, they would break easily.
Since aquatic plants can absorb water through the entire epidermis, importance of water conducting tissue is comparatively less.
In aquatic plants pollination generally occurs through water.
As a result fertilization is not ensured and sexual reproduction is hindered.
That is why, in most cases, aquatic plants act upon their reproduction vegetatively.
Xerophytic plants are adapted to special features for preservation and easy intake of water, limited use of preserved water and prevention of water loss.
Since xerophytic plants get little amount of water, they become small and bushy.
Leaves and stems of xrophytes are succulent due to storage of water.
Their tap root becomes very long because it has to collect water from deep under ground.
For easy absorption of water and mineral salts their dwarf branch roots remain wide spread with innumerable long root hair.
Stems become flat, leaf-like and green.
The epidermis of leaf is provided with thick-cuticle or thin waxy coating.
With little rainfall germination takes place and plants can produce flowers and fruits in short time.
Cells become small and are provided with thick walls so that they are not destroyed during extreme drought.
Mechanical tissues of xerophytes are highly developed so that they do not wilt during dry season.
Halophytes: Plants that grow in saline soil are called halophytes.
Keora, Sundari, Gewa, Goran.
Golpata, Pashur, Bora, Hindal etc are examples of halophytes.
All types of plants do not grow in saline soil.
Those plants which can adjust with saline soil and water, can grow in habitat.
Plants growing in the Sundarbans of our country are halophytes.
The halophytes in the tidal regions are called Mangrove plants.
Sundari, Gewa, Goran are mangrove plants.
They have some features which are not found in other plants.
In halophytes stems and le.aves are succulent and often modified to thorns or spines.
Plants develop stilt roots and prop roots so that they do not slant or lose ground because of tidal water.
Germination takes placer when the fruits remain attached with the plants.
This type of germination is called viviparous germination.
Roots and their branches are long and they spread up to a long distance just below the soil surface.
But the pneumatophores or breathing roots vertically come above the soil surface for easy exchange of gases.
Due to the presence of greater amount of salt in the cells the plants can absorb saline water.
Plants face difficulty in absorbing water from saline soil.
The degree of salinity reduces during sufficient rainfall.
At that time these plants store water in their cells.
As a result of which their cells, leaves, stems and roots remain succulent.
Everyday mangrove plants become regularly submerged during tidal bore.
Because of this phenomenon, prop roots and stilt roots develop from the stems and firmly attach the plants with soil.
As a result, the plants are not washed off by tidal water.
In these plants exchange of gases is obstructed because of water logging in soil.
To overcome this difficulty the pneumatophores or breathing roots develop in such plants.
These roots perform the exchange of gases coming as they come over the water surface.
Besides, there are large air cavities in these pneumatophores, which remain filled with oxygen.
Germination of seeds is impeded in saline soil.
Even if germination takes place, the seeds cease to live because of salinity.
To overcome this barrier, viviparous germination starts when the fruits remain attached to the branches.
As soon as the fruit falls on ground, its roots get fixed in the mud.
As a result, they do not float away by tidal waves.
To avoid the adverse effects of salinity, the branch roots of these plants are spread along the upper layer of the soil.
As a result they can easily exchange gases in the atmosphere.
Innumerable living and non-living objects of various types are found around us.
When various types of living organisms collectively exist in a place, an ecosystem develops among them.
For the survival of living organisms at a particular place or locality different relationships grow among living and non- living objects.
Development of such close relationship among living and non-living objects under a certain environment is known as ecosystem.
An ideal example of aquatic ecosystem is a small pond.
The close relationship among the living and non-living objects present in the pond may be clearly observed and easily understood.
The ecosystem of a pond is described below:
Abiotic component: These include water, dissolved oxygen, carbon dioxide, different inorganic salts etc.
The affectivity of ecosystem of a pond depends on how the biological components utilize these abiotic components.
Consumer: Aquatic insects, larvae, fishes, snails, shell fishes, stork, kite, etc are the consumers in this ecosystem.
Primary consumer: All animals which consume plants are known as primary consumers.
Examples-minute floating insects, larvae of mosquitoes, earthworms, zooplankton etc.
Secondary consumer: Animals which consume primary consumers are known as secondary consumers, such as-small fish, frog, other aquatic animals etc.
Tertiary consumer: Animals which feed on secondary consumers are called tertiary consumers.
Big fish, stork, kite, otter (Udbiral), hawk, eagle, water-fowl-all are tertiary consumers.
The decomposed inorganic substances and salts are again used by consumers as a natural process.
How does ecosystem maintain the balance of nature?
Ecosystem is a self sufficient unit and it is a one-way phenomenon.
The energy from the source flows towards the producers.
From producer it goes to consumer and from the consumer's body the energy is released in nature.
As a result of ecosystem balance is maintained in nature.
That is one living being binds another in the food chain because of this process.
Oneliving organism cannot get increased in number, nor can it become extinct.
Consequently, the number of living organisms remains constant in nature;
